The Refugee Agency is responsible for the admission and integration of Vietnamese refugees into Ireland. Its board is composed mainly of representatives of Government Departments. No appointments to the board have been made since 18 October 1991.

APSO's primary concern is the promotion and sponsorship of temporary personal services in developing countries. Since 18 October 1991 the Minister has made three appointments to the Board of APSO. The Agency's Articles of Association specifically provide for the immediate declaration by each board member of any interest which he or she may have in any contract matter or item under consideration at a meeting of the board.

Copies of the guidelines for State Bodies, prepared by the Minister of Finance and approved by the Government, have been forwarded to the Chairman of both APSO and the Refugee Agency with the Minister's request that the necessary steps be taken to ensure implementation of the guidelines insofar as they relate to their respective agencies.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Aid for Southern Africa.

Qst.Quest: if he has committed aid for the current emergency situation in Southern Africa; if he will outline the calendar of shipment and delivery that has been established for the pledged assistance in the light of the recently repeated appeals of various governments in the region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The countries of southern Africa, including South Africa, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi and Mozambique and parts of Zaire are experiencing one of the worst droughts of this century. South Africa should be able to meet its needs largely by commercial imports, but the other countries will need very substantial quantities of food aid.

While much of Ireland's disaster relief assistance has been directed towards the Horn of Africa, the Government have recently donated £150,000 in bilateral emergency aid in response to the situation in southern Africa. Of this, £50,000 was given to Trocaire for emergency feeding programmes in Malawi, Mozambique and Zimbabwe and £100,000 was given to the UN World Food programme for supplementary feeding programmes in Zambia. Further allocations will be considered, having regard to available resources for disaster relief.

The European Community has also acted swiftly. In addition to its normal food aid programme, a Special Emergency Programme of 800,000 tonnes of cereals has been agreed for Africa and other regions of the world affected by food shortages. Of this, 350,000 tonnes are destined for southern African countries. Ireland will contribute over £1 million to this in addition to our bilateral donation.

The Deputy asked about the calendar of shipment and delivery, presumably with regard to the EC Special Programme. Mobilisation of food to drought-affected areas of Africa began under the normal EC food aid programme, before the Special Programme was launched. The Commission is now in the process of concluding contracts with agents for delivery of the extra supplies at the earliest possible dates. The Community programme is an enormous undertaking and the precise detils have yet to be finalised.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement regarding the supply of heavy weapons, including Scud Missiles in substantial numbers, by the Government of North Korea to middle eastern countries; if he will outline the Government position on this matter; and if he has made or will make representations to the Government of North Korea in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware of reports regarding the supply of weapons, including Scud missiles, by North Korea to Middle-Eastern countries. Any supply of such weapons to regions of tension and instability like the Middle East, is always a matter of great concern.

Ireland, together with its EC partners, expressed concern about exports of conventional weapons in a Declaration on Non-Proliferation and Arms Exports which was adopted by the European Council at its meeting in Luxembourg on 29 June 1991.

This Declaration expressed alarm at the stockpiling of conventional weapons in certain regions of the world. To prevent situations of instability recurring in entire regions as a result of such overarmament, the European Council stated that far-reaching international action was needed immediately to promote restraint and transparency in the transfers of conventional weapons and of technologies for military use, in particular towards areas of tension. Ireland participated in the drafting of this Declaration and we give it our full support.

Ireland does not have diplomatic relations with North Korea. Nevertheless, in whatever contacts we may have with that country, we would certainly convey to them our views in line with the above Declaration.

Qst.Quest: whether this country have any plans to provide aid for Somalia to alleviate the appalling conditions there so graphically highlighted in a series of recent RTE reports; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will outline any specific plans he has to make funds available to voluntary organisations wishing to provide aid to the people of Somalia; and if he will provide a timetable for the implementation of these plans.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 44 and 48 together.

The Government are very concerned about the situation in Somalia, which has developed into an appalling human disaster since the outbreak of the civil war in 1991. Many thousands of people have lost their lives or been injured in the violence; there are serious food shortages due to drought as well as a massive displacement of persons.

The scale of the needs is so vast that the problem must be confronted at international level, and I am glad to say that, despite the critical security situation, in particular in Mogadishu, the United Nations and other relief agencies are pressing ahead with the relief effort.

Ireland is playing its part in the efforts to help the people of Somalia. So far this year £75,000 has been allocated from the Disaster Relief Fund to agencies involved in relief work there. In response to representations which have been made to me about the critical needs of Somalia, I have decided to allocate a further £50,000 to Concern and Goal to provide essential medicines and this money will be handed over later this week. This will bring the total Government bilateral contribution to £125,000 this year.

The European Community is helping with emergency relief and long term aid. The total value of EC assistance to Somalia so far is £24 million of which £10 million was allocated under the recently agreed Special Food Aid Programme.
On the political front, Ireland has fully supported and will continue to support the United Nations initiatives aimed at restoring peace in Somalia.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EC Documentation Distribution.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the retail price of a copy of (a) the Treaties establishing the European Communities as amended by the Single European Act and (b) the Maastricht Treaty Document including Protocols and declarations, through the Government Publications Office; if, in view of the cost of these documents, he will outline the steps he is taking to ensure that the information is available to the electorate to enable them to make an informed judgment on the Maastricht Agreement; if his attention has been drawn to plans by the Danish Government to make half a million free copies of the Maastricht document available to its citizens; if there are any plans for a similar distribution here; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government are making every effort to ensure that information is available to the electorate to enable them to make an informed judgment on the Treaty on European Union. The Government published a White Paper on the contents of the Treaty last month which is available from the Government Publications Sale Office at a price of £5. The Government have published a short guide to the Treaty which is being distributed without charge at present to all the householders in the country. Leaflets explaining particular aspects of the Treaty will be available before the Referendum.

The retail price of copies of the Treaties establishing the European Communities, as amended by the Single European Act is £80 for the two volume hardback set. However, an abridged paperback version of this publication which contains all the essential texts is available at £11.60.
Copies of the Maastricht Treaty on European Union retail at £6.95.
Both of these publications are available from the Government Publications Sale Office.

In order to facilitate access to the text of the Treaty on European Union to as many people as possible, arrangements have been made for copies of the Treaty to be available for perusal by members of the public in libraries and main post offices throughout the country.

MainHeading.P: The Government are aware of reports that the Danish Government have distributed half a million copies of the Treaty free of charge. It is estimated that the cost of circulating all of the households in the country would be in excess of £6 million including purchase and distribution costs. The Government are of the view that, having regard to the availability of the text of the Treaty in public libraries and main post offices, such an expensive distribution would be difficult to justify.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - UN Charter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: his views on whether the rights of minorities would be better protected if the UN Charter were amended to permit intervention in the internal affairs of member countries in the case of genocide or crimes against humanity; and whether he supports such a change.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Article 2.7 of the UN Charter provides that nothing in the Charter shall authorise the United Nations to intervene in matters which are essentially within the domestic jurisdiction of any state. This is of course without prejudice to the application of enforcement measures against a member state under Chapter VII.

The UN Charter also, however, contains a number of general provisions on human rights and these have been the basis for some important developments over nearly half a century notwithstanding the provisions of Article 2.7. Over that period, the Organisation has developed a network of major Human Rights Conventions and established a number of Commissions and other subsidiary bodies which do important work to promote Human Rights and to monitor their implementation.

MainHeading.P: The rights of minorities for example, are a particular concern of the Subcommission on the Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities established by the UN Commission on Human Rights. Genocide is a particularly appalling crime, involving as it does, an attempt not merely to discriminate against, but to eliminate a whole people. Genocide has been outlawed by the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide to which over one hundred states, including Ireland, are now parties. The Convention came into effect in 1951. Under its terms the Contracting Parties confirm that genocide, whether committed in time of peace or in time of war, is a crime under international law which they undertake to prevent and to punish.

While these provisions are important, I share the Deputy's concern to see better international protection for the rights of minorities. It is not realistic at present however to envisage doing this by way of a direct amendment of Article 2.7 of the UN Charter. Any amendment of the Charter, would, in accordance with Article 108, require the support of two-thirds of the member states, including that of all five Permanent Members of the Security Council. Such support for an amendment of Article 2.7 does not exist at present.

I would add that Ireland has always insisted that all States are under obligation to uphold fundamental human rights and to implement in full their commitments under international human rights instruments. We do not see efforts by the international community to secure implementation of human rights in accordance with the UN Charter as in any way an unwarranted interference in a country's internal affairs.

Qst.Quest: if he has plans for any new initiatives in the Anglo Irish context in view of the appointment of a new Northern Ireland Secretary and other political developments; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware, the Government are currently involved in a process of political talks whose object is to achieve a new beginning for relationships within Northern Ireland, within the island of Ireland and between the peoples of these islands.

In our contacts with the new British Government, we have made clear the high priority which we attach to the search for political progress in relation to Northern Ireland. Our purpose in entering these talks is to pursue a comprehensive political settlement based upon the three sets of relationships involved and capable of bringing lasting peace, stability and prosperity to this island. It is our earnest hope that, with a sufficiently open, constructive and forward-looking approach on the part of all participants, this objective may be realised.

Qst.Quest: whether there is any onus on honorary envoys to provide a consular service of some kind; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Under Article 5 of the Vienna Convention on Consular relations, Honorary Consuls have the same functions as career Consuls. In Irish practice, however, Honorary Consuls are not expected to carry out the full range of functions set out under this Article. The main consular functions performed by our Honorary Consuls are as follows: (1) providing assistance and advice to Irish citizens. This includes: providing emergency consular assistance; registering Irish citizens; processing passport applications; answering citizenship queries; and maintaining contact with the Irish community, (2) processing visa applications of aliens who require visas to enter Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 63 and 65 together.

MainHeading.P: The Review of Industrial Performance 1990 which was undertaken by my Department, examined, inter alia, the position of overseas industry in Ireland and their contribution to the Irish economy. There are almost 1,000 overseas firms in Ireland, which, between them, employ some 90,000 people. This is equivalent to 40 per cent of the industrial workforce. They account for 50 per cent of manufactured output and three quarters of industrial exports.

The Irish Economy Expenditure survey carried out on an annual basis by the IDA analyses the expenditure by overseas companies located here on Irish services, raw materials and wages and salaries. The 1990 Survey (latest figures available) showed that total Irish economy expenditure of overseas industry amounted to £3,744 million broken down as follows:
According to the IDA the growth rate in total Irish economy expenditure for the period 1983-1990 was 51.3 per cent broken down as follows:

The recent Culliton Report on Industrial Policy has acknowledged the benefits accruing to the Irish economy from the foreign firms located here and the additional benefits generated by their spin-off demand.

Apart from their Irish economy expenditure I understand from the IDA that in general multinational companies already contribute significantly to local community initiatives in their area. I understand that numerous activities are assisted in this way throughout the country including community development and job creation generally.

I also understand from the IDA that the current capital grant agreement which multinational companies in the manufacturing and international services sectors enter into with the Authority incorporates features for the control and security of the monies paid.
These are as follows:

—A clawback clause where grants are required to be repaid in the event of failure to maintain job targets.

The IDA have informed me that all grantees must also comply with a number of conditions when submitting a claim for grant payment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Parents' Schools Contribution.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline his policy on the levying of voluntary contributions from parents in second level schools; whether he considers that a contribution of £100 per child is in breach of the Free Education Scheme; and if he takes any action against schools which seek to levy such contributions through final notices and bills marked overdue.

if he will outline his policy in relation to schools which levy a voluntary contribution of £60 to secure a place in first year of second level; and whether such contributions are in breach of the commitment in the introduction to the Green Paper to non-selective entry to second level schools for children in the catchment area.

if he will outline the influence or power he or his Department has regarding the admissions policy of second level schools receiving public funding; whether he can specify to a second level school that it should take pupils from a geographically defined catchment area before taking pupils from outside the said area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 96, 97 and 100 together.

In the case of secondary schools, I presume that the questions refer to schools in the Free Education Scheme. The basic condition for entry to that scheme is that payment would not be sought in respect of
1. Instruction in any subject listed in the general school programme,
2. Recreational or study facilities of which all the pupils are expected to avail themselves as part of the school programme,
3. Any other activity in which all pupils are required to take part.

Subject to these conditions, it would be in order for schools in the scheme to accept contributions of a voluntary nature, provided that it is made clear to parents that these contributions are entirely voluntary and are not a condition for the admission of pupils.

I wish to put on record that I am opposed to selection tests for the purpose of enrolment of children in post-primary schools. I am eqully opposed to the imposition of charges on a non-voluntary basis on parents in respect of the enrolment of their children.
I shall be happy to have my Department investigate any case in which the Deputy considers a school to be in breach of the conditions of participation in the Free Education Scheme.

MainHeading.P: The country is divided into post primary catchment areas for the purposes of school transport and provision of post-primary school accommodation. My concern is to make adequate provision to cater for the overall post-primary needs of the pupils of these catchment areas. The admission of pupils is, however, a matter for the individual school authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Education of Mildly Handicapped.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline his Department's policy in connection with the education of mildly mentally handicapped people, in particular at post-primary level; and if he will further outline the post-primary schools in Dublin 3, 5 or 9 which have been assisted by his Department to cater for the needs of pupils assessed as being mildly mentally handicapped.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: My Department provides for the education of children with mild mental handicap at primary level in a number of ways.

Integration of such children into the mainstream education is encouraged, where appropriate, but provision is also made for those who cannot be successfully integrated. These children may attend special schools or special classes in ordinary national schools.

At present, there are 32 special schools and 151 special classes for mildly mentally handicapped children. In addition, there have been a number of recent initiatives under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, targeted specifically at the needs of such children.
These initiatives include:
—7 new resource teacher posts
—6 additional visiting teacher posts
—a reduction in the pupil/teacher ratio in special schools for mildly mentally handicapped.

The Special Education Review Committee will be examining the question of appropriate provisions for children with special needs, including those with mild mental handicap, and I will give due consideration to whether additional measures are appropriate in the light of the Committee's recommendations.

The key principle which informs my Department's policy in relation to the education of mildly handicapped pupils at post-primary level is that, where appropriate, such education should be provided in special classes in ordinary schools, rather than in special schools.

MainHeading.P: In order to assist post-primary schools to cater for the needs of pupils assessed as being mildly handicapped, my Department will authorise a teaching post in the appropriate post-primary school in addition to the normal quota.

It is not normal practice for my Department to list individual schools which have been allocated additional teaching resources. However, eight second level schools in Dublin 3, 5 and 9 areas have been allocated teachers to cater for the needs of the mildly mentally handicapped.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the reduction in teacher numbers which has been estimated will result from his decision to refuse recognition for teacher employment purposes to sixth class primary school repeat pupils.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the amount of finance which it has been estimated will be saved by his decision to refuse recognition for pupil/teacher ratio and teacher employment/appointment purposes of the pupils repeating sixth class.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 112, 113 and 114 together.
Statistics supplied to my Department by primary schools, relating to enrolment on 30 September 1991, indicates that 1,898 pupils were enrolled in sixth class for the second time.

The exclusion of pupils repeating sixth class in reckoning a school's enrolment for staffing purposes does not necessarily result in the loss of a teaching post, or refusal for an additonal appointment. The appointment and retention of teachers is governed by an enrolments schedule and, depending on where a school's enrolment figure occurs on the schedule, exclusion of the pupils in question may have no effect on the number of teachers warranted in the school.

Under the provisions of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress over-all teacher numbers during the Programme are related to the national pupil/teacher ratio. Accordingly, the schedule governing teacher appointments is adjusted so that numbers of posts being reduced are matched by numbers of posts added.

MainHeading.P: My Department does not keep separate statistics on the number of cases of the kind referred to by the Deputy occurring in any given school year. However, the number of schools affected is small.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn)

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the Government policy for handicapped people to avail of public transport and, in particular, if she will outline if any of the present DART carriages are fitted with an automatic ramp for use by the handicapped or if any new DART carriages purchased will have such ramps.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn) Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn)
Speaker.P: As indicated in paragraph 117 of the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, it is Government policy that transport providers must, on an ongoing basis, give attention to improving accessibility to transport for persons with disabilities, as resources permit. The InterDepartmental Transport Accessibility Committee, chaired by my Department, are charged with establishing priorities for attention and with advising transport providers as to the appropriate measures to be taken in their particular circumstances. In doing their work, the Committee have maintained regular contact with representative organisations concerned.
Passenger carriages on DART trains can be accessed directly from station platforms without any need for a ramp. Accordingly, Iarnród Éireann does not propose to fit such ramps.
Improving access to DART or other rail services is a matter for Iarnród Éireann, as resources permit. I regret that there are no funds at my disposal for the purpose.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: There are a number of initiatives underway at present which when completed will help to improve the lives of persons with autism.

The Eastern and Western Health Boards, in conjunction with the Irish Society for Autism are currently carrying out surveys on the extent of autism in their respective regions which will help to identify the needs of that population. The Department's mental handicap adviser has also been asked to examine the present services available to persons with autism and to make recommendations which will enhance those services.

MainHeading.P: A major development for persons with autism is planned on a site made available by the Daughters of Charity, St. Vincent's Hospital, Fairview, Dublin 3. This will involve the provision of a workshop for 30 trainees and two houses providing 6 residential places. It is expected that construction will commence before the end of this year.
Improvements in the specialist assessment of autistic children are also being facilitated as a result of developments in the child psychiatric services.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Counselling for Child Abusers.

Qst.Quest: if, in light of the increasing number of child abuse cases currently being reported, he will outline any specific plans he has to provide counselling for the perpetrators of these crimes, and if he will provide a timetable for the implementation of these reforms.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Specialist conselling services for perpetrators of child sex abuse are available at the Central Mental Hospital, Dundrum and at Usher's Island, Dublin and are administered by the Eastern Health Board. Counselling services for adolescent abusers are also provided at the Children's Hospital, Temple Street, Dublin.

The programmes in operation at the Central Mental Hospital, Dundrum and Usher's Island have been developed as part of a National Forensic Service developed by the Eastern Health Board and referrals to these programmes are taken from all health board areas. The programmes are run by multi-disciplinary teams of health professionals and are aimed at helping the abusers examine their offending behaviour, their sexuality and the victim experience.

Speaker.P: Professor David Kennedy, Chairman of the Dublin Hospital Advisory Group, submitted a report on the Tallaght Hospital Project to me last week. Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the report in the Irish Medical Journal to the effect that GP's casualty referrals are the highest in Europe, and if he will outline the action he proposes to take.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I am aware of the report referred to by the Deputy and I am having the issues raised in the findings of the report examined by my Department. It is one of my priorities as Minister for Health to strengthen the role of the general practitioner and to improve the interface between the general practitioner and the hospital services so that patients receive treatment at the level most appropriate to their condition. As the Deputy may be aware, my Department and the health boards are currently involved with representatives of general practitioners in a major review of the General Medical Services Scheme which will include an examination of ways of improving co-ordination between general practitioner and acute hospital services.

Medical card holders are entitled to health services free of charge including access to general practitioner services. Medical card holders should therefore, consult their general practitioner in the first instance who will be in the best position to advise on an appropriate treatment or arrange for specialist referral if required.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Alarm System for the Elderly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell

This system is based on the recommendations of The Years Ahead which were that the long term goal of each health board should be to provide a telephone or radio based alarm to elderly persons living alone and assessed by the district team for the elderly as being at medical or social risk. It is the policy of my Department to encourage health boards to provide alarm systems as part of their overall services for the elderly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The Disabled Person's (Maintenance Allowance Regulations, 1991, provided for a change in the method of payment of the allowance to couples, married or co-habiting, where both partners are in receipt of DPMA or where one is in receipt of DPMA and the other in receipt of a Social Welfare payment. The effect of the change, which brought DPMA into line with Social Welfare legislation, was that couples in such cases receive the equivalent of one full personal rate and one adult dependent rate.
I am curently reviewing the situation of couples who were in receipt of DPMA at a high rate prior to the introduction of the 1991 Regulations.
In the meantime health boards have been requested that there be no reduction in the amount of DPMA paid to such couples.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Infant Death Statistics.

Qst.Quest: the number of babies who die each year from sudden infant death syndrome; if there are suspected causes; if he will outline the precautions which can be taken; if the monitoring devices which are available on the market are of any benefit, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The number of children under one year of age who died suddenly and where the cause of death was unknown in each of the last 4 years is as follows:

MainHeading.P: *Provisional

The causes of Sudden Infant Death are not known. As a result of recent studies concerning Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (Cot Death) and following consultation between the Chief Medical Officer of the Department of Health and the Faculty of Paediatrics of the Royal College of Physicians in Ireland, my Department recommend the following guidelines which may help parents and those caring for babies to reduce the risk of Sudden Infant Deaths:
—a baby should be placed on his or her back or side to sleep
—babies should not be allowed to become too warm
—expectant mothers should not smoke nor allow anyone to smoke near the baby during the first year of life
—if at all possible mothers should breastfeed babies for the first few weeks, not because this in itself reduces the risk of cot death, but because it may reduce the risk of infection.

In 1991 a grant of £24,500 was made from the National Lottery funds to the Irish Sudden Infant Death Association (ISIDA) and further grants of £23,000 are committed in both 1992 and 1993 towards the cost of establishing a national register of cot deaths. This register will form a valuable data base for research into the problem.

The use of appropriate monitoring devices may from time to time be recommended by a family doctor or a Public Health Nurse. Families who are concerned are advised to contact their family doctor or Public Health Nurse on those matters.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - International Agencies Jobs.

Qst.Quest: if he intends to advertise publicly all jobs relating to international agencies as soon as they become available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: As the Deputy may be aware from a reply given on the topic of vacancies in international organisations to Deputy Higgins on 11 December last, primary responsibility for this matter rests with the Minister for Finance, whose Department circulates notices received of vacancies in international organisations. These notices are circulated by that Department to the main FÁS offices, to the universities, to the semi-state organisations, to the Health Boards and within the civil service.

MainHeading.P: In addition every month the Department of Foreign Affairs circulates to interested parties in a document called “The Abstract of Technical Assistance” a list of current technical vacancies in international organisations. Circulation of this document varies from 250 to 500 and any individual who wishes to be included in its circulation may do so by contacting the Development Co-operation Division of the Department of Foreign Affairs.

Qst.Quest: whether the ratification of the Maastricht Treaty includes the ratification of the Protocols attached to the Treaty; if the EC Council at Maastricht nominated a final date for ratification by member states; if so, if he will outline the date; and, if not, if he will outline the date the Government propose for ratification and for the consequential referendum.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Treaty on European Union includes the text of the Treaty itself and of the Protocols attached to it. The Protocols are an integral part of the text of the Treaty and are subject to the same ratification process.

The Treaty (Article R) specifies that “the Treaty shall enter into force on 1 January 1993, provided that all the instruments of ratification have been deposited, or, failing that, on the first day of the month following the deposit of the instrument of ratification by the last signatory to take this step”.

As far as this country is concerend it is the Government's intention to complete the necessary formal procedures to enable ratification of the Treaty by the end of this year. A referendum will be necessary to amend the Constitution so as to permit ratification. This referendum will be held on l8th June 1992.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline any specific plans he has to initiate reforms which would facilitate the writing off of Third World debt; and if he will provide a timetable for the implementation of these reforms.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware of the problems arising from the heavy burden of debt carried by many Third World countries. This is a major issue for the world community and it needs to be tackled at global level.

The role which the Government can play is to support the efforts being made by the international financial institutions to resolve the problem and we are doing this, in so far as we can, through our membership of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

Within the European Community, we have also given our support to measures under STABEX, the Community fund set up under the Lomé Conventions, which involve the forgiveness of debts of the ACP countries who have signed the Convention.

Qst.Quest: if, in regard to the Government's attendance as observers at the recent meeting of the Western European Union, it is intended to attend further such meetings; if he will outline the basis on which attendance at such meetings will be determined; if he will make available to Members of the Oireachtas the platform adopted by the Western European Union in 1987; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, the Government were represented, as observer, at a Ministerial meeting of the Western European Union Council which took place at the time of the Maastricht European Council last December. At this meeting, the Western European Union discussed its future relations with the European Union and the invitation to be issued to members of the European Union to become members or observers of the Western European Union.

The Government had previously attended as observer two earlier meetings of the Western European Union Council which were convened last year to consider the Yugoslav crisis and the steps the Western European Union might take to support the European Community's peace process including its Monitor Mission.

In all three cases, the Government's decision to attend as observer was based on their desire to be fully informed on all developments that would have a bearing on matters under discussion within the European Community.

Pending a decision by Government on the response to be given to the invitation from the member states of the Western European Union to States which are members of the European Union to accede to the Western European Union or to become observers, the question of the future representation of the Government, as observer, at any future meetings of the Ministerial Council of the Western European Union will be considered on the same basis as attendance at the meetings to which I have already referred.

With regard to the Platform adopted by the Western European Union in 1987, I have arranged for copies of this to be placed in the Dáil Library. In this connection, I would like to point out that this Platform is binding on member states of the Western European Union only. Attendance at Western European Union meetings as an observer would not require Ireland to take up any obligations under the Brussels Treaty or to subscribe to policy positions or platforms adopted by the Western European Union.

Qst.Quest: if he can intercede to protect the underground children in Colombia; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The question of underground and street children not only in Colombia but in other countries of Latin America, for example Brazil, has been one of concern both to Ireland and to our partners in the European Community for some considerable time. The European Community and its member states have instructed their Ambassadors in Latin American countries to monitor closely the situation of underground and street children and to report regularly on the matter. Governments in the region are being actively encouraged at every opportunity to do all in their power to resolve this problem.
I can assure the Deputy that I will continue to monitor closely the situation of these children.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Title V of the Treaty on European Union contains the provisions of a Common Foreign and Security Policy and is an integral part of the Treaty copies of which may be obtained from the Government Publications Office. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Passport Office Arrangements.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make special provision, in the Passport Office, to people who require a new or renewal of their passport, due to the extraordinary long delays in the Passport Office which have been compounded by the present postal dispute; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I would like to assure the Deputy that I am personally concerned about the delays being experienced by members of the public in obtaining passports as a result of the current postal dispute.

MainHeading.P: The Passport Office processes approximately 180,000 passport applications each year. On average 30 per cent of these are issued during the months of May and June; 60 per cent of all applications are normally submitted and delivered through the postal system. As a result of the postal dispute the vast majority of these applications are being submitted and collected in person.

The very large increase in the number of persons calling to the Passport Office is causing considerable difficulties both for members of the public and for the Passport Office. To date the following measures have been taken: about 80 extra members of staff have been recruited on a temporary basis, in addition to the normal staff complement of about 40; extra overtime is being worked; the Passport Office is being opened each Saturday to facilitate the collection of passports; priority is being given to those members of the public who are travelling in the immediate future; arrangements are also in place so that members of the public may deliver their applications and/or collect their passports either in person, through a courier or by an agreed third party.
The situation is being monitored on a daily basis and we will continue to review the possibility of additional measures which might help to alleviate the current problems.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Anglo-Irish Agreement.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline his intentions as to the future development of the Anglo-Irish Agreement; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government have embarked on a process of talks with the British Government and the main constitutional political parties in Northern Ireland with the object of achieving a new beginning for relationships within Northern Ireland, within the island of Ireland and between the peoples of these islands.

The two Governments, as signatories of the Anglo-Irish Agreement, have made clear that they would be prepared to consider a new and more broadly based agreement or structure if such an arrangement can be arrived at.

MainHeading.P: It has also been made clear, however, that the Anglo-Irish Agreement will remain in place and will continue to be implemented fully unless and until new arrangements are agreed which would transcend it. The Government will seek to ensure that progress continues to be made in those areas which have been our priority concern since the Agreement was signed. We will also be considering ways in which the work of the Conference could usefully be strengthened and extended, particularly in the economic and social sectors.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)

Special arrangements are provided for small abattoirs handling under 1,000 livestock units per annum; such abattoirs will continue to be governed by the standards of the Abattoirs Act, 1988. (One livestock unit equals 1 bovine or 7 sheep or 3 pigs). Abattoirs handling over 1,000 livestock units per annum which cannot meet the requirements of the Directive will be given a derogation until 1995, provided the proprietors submit appropriate improvement plans.

MainHeading.P: Irish meat is a quality product and only the highest standards of production are acceptable. It is essential, therefore, that operators comply with the Directive requirements as soon as possible.
The information provided was not sufficient to identify the abattoir in question. If the Deputy contacts me or the Department with further details I will have the case examined.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Farmyard Pollution Control.

Qst.Quest: if it is Government policy to continue with the elimination of farmyard pollution; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that no further processing of such application can be dealt with due to a shortage of funds; if he will make such funds available immediately; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Under the scheme for the Control of Farmyard Pollution (CFP) which was introduced in Ireland in 1989 as an Operational Programme, a sum of £66.4 million was made available from the Structural Funds to finance expenditure over the years 1989-1993.
To date 27,000 farmers have applied for the scheme and approvals have issued in 25,000 cases leaving over 2,000 to be dealt with. These approvals have exhausted Ireland's allocation under the Scheme.

As all the outstanding approvals are unlikely to reach completion it has been decided to cancel those approvals where the completion date has expired. This should release some of the committed funds and make it possible to deal with a substantial number of applications on hands within the current financial allocation.

The cancellation of approvals where the completion date has expired will still leave over 10,000 approved projects under the CFP Scheme where work is incomplete. These outstanding approvals are sufficient to ensure that pollution control work will continue under the Scheme into late 1993. In addition grants for this type of work continue to be available under the Farm Improvement Programme.

Qst.Quest: if he will ensure that, at meat factories where TB reactor cattle are slaughtered, a blood test will be carried out to verify whether disease was actually present in the animals or not so as to definitely inform such livestock owners as to the prevalence of the disease where there are no lesions showing in the carcasses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The existing intradermal tuberculin test is the officially recognised test for bovine TB, both at EC level and internationally and there are no proposals to diminish the status of that test. The absence of visible lesions at post mortem examination does not mean that the animal does not have bovine TB. In some cases reactor animals will have been identified before lesions develop while in other cases, lesions, though present, may be so small as to be undetectable by visual examination.

It is hoped that in the future a suitable blood test could be used to augment the tuberculin test. In this regard a number of research projects into the development of diagnostic blood based tests are being undertaken. While the results are encouraging it will be necessary to carry out extensive field trials to assess their effectiveness.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Bovine TB Testing Dispute.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the steps being taken to resolve the dispute with vets over Bovine TB testing; and when normal testing, which has been in abeyance for two years, will recommence.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Discussions are ongoing with the Irish Veterinary Union in regard to the EC Commission's requirement for a changed method of allocation of testing to veterinary surgeons. Meeting this requirement would enable drawdown of EC funding amounting to at least £30 million over a 3 year period.

Under the current arrangements a herdowner can obtain a herd test on request. Almost one third of the country's 172,000 herds had a test in 1992 which is a higher than normal rate of progress for an annual round. A comprehensive testing programme amounting to 8 million animal tests which focused on restricted and contiguous herds was carried out in 1991.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Prior to early May an information service was provided by my Department at the office on Sundrive Road on Mondays and Thursdays of each week.
The Information Officer who attended this office has recently been transferred on promotion.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Free Telephone Rental Allowance.

Qst.Quest: if a person (details supplied) in County Kildare will be reconsidered for a free telephone rental allowance in view of the special circumstances; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The person concerned applied for Free Telephone Rental Allowance in January 1992. One of the conditions for receipt of this allowance is that the applicant must reside alone or only with children under 15 years of age or with other persons who are so permanently incapacitated as to be unable to summon assistance in the event of an emergency.

The person concerned resides with his wife and their four young children. As his wife does not suffer from any physical incapacity which would prevent her from summoning assistance in the event of an emergency, his application for the allowance had to be rejected. The person concerned was notified of this decision.

I appreciate the difficult circumstances in which the person concerned and his family find themselves. However, it would not be possible to make an exception to the rules of the scheme in this type of case without discriminating against other persons who might be in a similar situation.

Qst.Quest: the date of the appeal hearing in relation to the disability benefit claim of a person (details supplied) in Waterford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed Disability Benefit from 30 August 1991 and was paid up to 18 December 1991 when, following an examination by a Medical Referee, she was deemed to be capable of work. She appealed against this decision to the independent Social Welfare Appeals Office and she was referred for a further medical examination by a different Medical Referee who also deemed her capable of work. Her appeal was referred to an Appeals Officer who proposes to hold an oral hearing of her appeal. This will be arranged for the week commencing 15 June 1992. The person concerned has been in receipt of Unemployment Benefit pending the determination of her appeal.
